content:
My first suggestion is to verify that the SMTP server is for that account. To do that, - click 'account settings' - click the account name in left sidebar - now, on bottom line in right side of screen, click the 'edit SMTP server' button - on next screen, verify that the email account is correct, and not for one of your other accounts - if it is for another account, go back to prior screen and click the drop-down menu for outgoing SMTP server and set to the right server.

The above may not be relevant, but it is a common problem when a user has multiple accounts with same provider.

If you have any other ideas/ suggestions, I would appreciate it.
creator: rkovacs

content:
please understand that thunderbird does not use points, but pixels. You need to increase the size from 11 to 15. And, from the article I gave you, set the desired font to both the latin and the other one for all fonts, including the minimum size.

Further, from the article I gave you, Thunderbird does NOT include font size in emails unless you force large or extra large or small. The font size you see on screen is for you. If sent without font size - or as plain text - the recipient's email client sets the size. That is why I recommend setting the HTML composition font to variable width, as that frees the recipient to see the font in his/her chosen font and font size.
creator: davidsk

content:
If you are using an IMAP mail account, then it an only display whatever is on server.

If you have another device accessing server eg: phone or another laptop etc, is it also using Imap? If it's using Pop then it may be downloading from Inbox and deleting off server, so email then gets deleted from the Thunderbird imap view. Also check to see if you have another email client still operating on computer. i did comes across someone who used to use Outlook and discovered it was still working in the background. As that was originally set up as Pop, it was responsible for deleting off server. Pop accounts need to be set up to 'Leave messages on server'

Do you have any 'Message Filters' that mention a Delete?
creator: Toad-Hall

content: Most likely you do have an email account with your ISP, but you aren't connected to the Internet via your ISP. Your ISP does require you connect through them to be able send mail through their SMTP server.

content:
Menu app icon > Density There are three settings: Compact, Default and Relaxed

The spacing may look different if you have a different font size. Menu app icon > Font Size Check to see if have the same on each computer.

However, you might have different screen resolution on each computer which would alter the pixel size, so it might be worth checking to see if that is also effecting your visual view of things. You may find a font size of 14 is ok on one computer but works beter using 16 on the other.

content:
I suggest you upload an image of this.

Please tell us: what OS you are using what version of Thunderbird are you using Are you talking about a Pop or Imap account ?

Just had a thought...Does that message mention something like 'Compact' to save disk space ? If yes, that means doing some basic maintenance on files.

When you delete or move emails, those emails get 'marked as deleted' because they are not required in that file any more, but they are hidden from your view. In reality they are still in the mbox file. Compacting means removing all those old 'marked as deleted' emails, thus cleaning up file, saving space and helping to maintian a healthy file - reduces risk of corruption. Info on compacting :

  • https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/compacting-folders

content:
Hi Bob.

First, the most simple explanation:

You just need to enter the right password. If you don't know it, you must re-set it and get a new one. You cannot change an account password in Thunderbird. You must do it through you e-mail service provider. After you have a new password with Optimum, you will enter it into Thunderbird when Thunderbird asks you for it.


Second, the next most simple explanation:

Since you can receive but not send messages, there is a problem with your settings. I suggest that you call Optimum and ask for the SMTP settings for suddenlink accounts. Make sure that you get: server name, port, user name, authentication method, and type of connection security. Then go into account settings in Thunderbird, select "Outgoing Server" in the left pane, select the SMTP server in the right pane, and make sure that the right information is entered.

On the Web, I found:

Server name: smtp.suddenlink.net User name: full e-mail address Port: 465 Connection security: SSL

I have not found the authentication method. At a minimum, make sure that it is something other than insecure transmission of password. Ask Optimum what it should be.

While you're talking with Optimum, have them confirm your incoming mail settings too. In Thunderbird, they are in account settings > server settings.


Third, the least likely explanation:

I don't know how PayPal would know that someone is trying to access your mail. Maybe they are getting tracking information when messages from them are opened by a hacker from a different IP address.

If the PayPal people are correct, then these two symptoms may be related. The first thing that a hacker would do is change your account password to lock you out of your account.

In your place, I would ask Optimum for help. They can probably help explain what is happening, and they can help you re-set your password and re-gain control of your account.

This explanation makes no sense to me if you are able to receive messages.
creator: mozilla98
